sen.j: 活津日子命（古事記）あるいは活津彦根命（日本書紀）とは、アマテラスとスサノオの誓約によって生まれた5男3女の四男で、アマテラスが左手に巻いていた玉から生まれた神。
sen.e: Ikutsuhikone-no-mikoto, written as 活津日子命 (in Kojiki: The Records of Ancient Matters) or 活津彦根命 (in Nihonshoki: Chronicles of Japan), is the fourth son in five sons and three daughters given birth of the pledge made by Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) and Susano (Amaterasu's brother: a deity in Japanese Mythology), and he was born from a bead which Amaterasu was wearing on her left wrist.

Ikutsuhikone-no-mikoto, written as 活津日子命 (in Kojiki: The Records of Ancient Matters) or 活津彦根命 (in Nihonshoki: Chronicles of Japan), is the fourth son in five sons and three daughters given birth from the pledge made by Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) and Susano (Amaterasu's brother: a deity in Japanese Mythology), and he was born from a bead which Amaterasu was wearing on her left wrist.

Ikutsuhikone no mikoto, written as 活津日子命 (in Kojiki: The Records of Ancient Matters) or 活津彦根命 (in Nihonshoki: Chronicles of Japan), is the fourth son in five sons and three daughters given birth from the pledge made by Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) and Susano (Amaterasu's brother: a deity in Japanese Mythology), and he was born from a bead which Amaterasu was wearing on her left wrist.

sen.j: 出口延経の死後、外宮 神官の桑原弘雄、弘世父子によって整理、1733年に完成し、延喜式 神名帳記載神社の考証を行った神名帳考証によると、忍坂と住吉にある生根神社の祭神（現在は少彦名命等）とされる。
sen.e: According to Jimmyocho Kosho: historical investigation on shrines listed in Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), which was organized after Nobutsune DEGUCHI's death and completed in 1733 by Hiro KUWAHARA, a Shinto priest of Geku (the outer shrine of Ise), and his son 弘世, Ikutsuhikone is defined as the enshrined deity of Ikune-jinja Shrine (presently enshrines Sukunahikona-no-mikoto and others) in Oshisaka (also pronounced as Ossaka or Osaka) and Sumiyoshi.

According to Jimmyocho Kosho: historical investigation on shrines listed in Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), which was organized after Nobutsune DEGUCHI's death and completed in 1733 by Hiro KUWAHARA, a Shinto priest of Geku (the outer shrine of Ise), and his son 弘世, Ikutsuhikone is defined as the enshrined deity of Ikune-jinja Shrine (presently enshrines Sukunahikona-no-mikoto and others) in Oshisaka (also pronounced as Ossaka or Osaka) and Sumiyoshi.

According to Jinmyocho Kosho: historical investigation on shrines listed in Engishiki jinmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), which was organized after Nobutsune DEGUCHI's death and completed in 1733 by Hiro KUWAHARA, a Shinto priest of Geku (the outer shrine of Ise), and his son 弘世, Ikutsuhikone is defined as the enshrined deity of Ikune jinja Shrine (presently enshrines Sukunahikona no mikoto and others) in Oshisaka (also pronounced as Ossaka or Osaka) and Sumiyoshi.
sen.cmt: 用語統一ハイフン削除

sen.j: 生国魂神社の祭神とも同神とされる。
sen.e: He is considered to be the same god as the one enshrined to Ikukunitama-jinja Shrine.
He is considered to be the same god as the one enshrined to Ikukunitama-jinja Shrine.
He is considered to be the same god as the one enshrined to Ikukunitama-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 他に天田郡生野神社、養父郡伊久刀神社等の祭神。
sen.e: He is also enshrined to Ikuno-jinja Shrine in Amata-gun, Ikuto-jinja Shrine in Yabu-gun, and so on.
He is also enshrined to Ikuno-jinja Shrine in Amata-gun, Ikuto-jinja Shrine in Yabu-gun, and so on.
He is also enshrined to Ikuno-jinja Shrine in Amata-gun, Ikuto-jinja Shrine in Yabu-gun, and so on.

sen.j: 大己貴命と何らかの関係がある様であるが、不明。
sen.e: He seems to have some sort of relation to Onamuchi-no-mikoto, but the details are unclear.
He seems to have some sort of relation to Onamuchi-no-mikoto, but the details are unclear.
He seems to have some sort of relation to Onamuchi no mikoto, but the details are unclear.

sen.j: 関連のある神名としては生島神、大八島之霊、生玉、活日？、生田？等が考えられる。
sen.e: Shinmyo (name of a god) considered to be related to Ikutsuhikone include Ikushima-no-kami, Oyashima-no-mitama, Ikutama, 活田?, 生田? and so on.
sen.cmt: 原文「活日？、生田？」の部分は、漢字の読みも「？」に当てはまる文字も不明のため、訳文にも原文のまま記載しました。
sen.e: Shinmyo (name of a god) considered to be related to Ikutsuhikone include Ikushima-no-kami, Oyashima-no-mitama, Ikutama, 活田?, 生田? and so on.
Shinmyo (name of a god) considered to be related to Ikutsuhikone include Ikushima no kami, Oyashima no mitama, Ikutama, 活田?, 生田? and so on.

sen.j: 滋賀県にある彦根の地名はこの神の名に起こるという。
sen.e: The place-name of Hikone, Shiga Prefecture, is said to be named after the god.
The place-name of Hikone, Shiga Prefecture, is said to be named after the god.
The place-name of Hikone, Shiga Prefecture, is said to be named after the god.

sen.j: この神の後裔氏族は見当たらないが、新撰姓氏録にタカミムスビの子の伊久魂命の後裔として恩智神社の神主が載っている。
sen.e: Although any clan has not been identified as the god's descendant, a Shinto priest of Onji-jinja Shrine is listed in Shinsen Shojiroku (genealogical table of ancient clans) as a descendant of Ikumusubi-no-mikoto, a child of Takamimusubi.

Although any clan has not been identified as the god's descendant, a Shinto priest of Onji-jinja Shrine is listed in Shinsen Shojiroku (genealogical table of ancient clans) as a descendant of Ikumusubi-no-mikoto, a child of Takamimusubi.

Although any clan has not been identified as the god's descendant, a Shinto priest of Onji jinja Shrine is listed in Shinsen Shojiroku (genealogical table of ancient clans) as a descendant of Ikumusubi no mikoto, a child of Takamimusubi.

tit.j: イクツヒコネを祀る主な神社

sen.j: 彦根神社（滋賀県彦根市）
sen.e: Hikone-jinja Shrine (Hikone City, Shiga Prefecture)
Hikone-jinja Shrine (Hikone City, Shiga Prefecture)

sen.j: 活津彦根神社（滋賀県蒲生郡安土町）
